articles.title: Sheep kurt: The tradition of Kazakh dairy
articles.summary: Up until the beginning of the 20th century, sheep’s milk was the base for all dairy products in Kazakhstan.
articles.content:
This story by Aliya Bolatkhan (translated from Russian by Beatrice Learmouth) first appeared in vlast.kz on September 17, 2025. This edited version is being republished on Global Voices under a content partnership agreement.

Historian Aliya Bolatkhan describes how butter and kurt (a traditional dried cheese snack made from fermented sheep’s milk) are made in southern Kazakhstan. One hundred years ago, this was common practice, but it is now much rarer. In this article, we take you through a valley only accessible on horseback, where villagers preserve this forgotten practice.

The history of sheep’s milk in Kazakhstan

Up until the beginning of the 20th century, sheep’s milk was the base for all dairy products in Kazakhstan. In the late 17th century, horses and sheep dominated herds, while cows and camels accounted for just 1 percent of livestock. Even as late as 1922, an ethnographic survey found that cow’s milk represented only about 10 percent of a Kazakh family’s dairy consumption.

Cows were not seen as a valuable asset by nomadic people, as they required much more care than other animals, complicating long journeys. Plus, sheep’s milk is more nutritious than cow’s milk in terms of calories, fat, and protein.

During the Russian colonization, cows became more commonplace due to closer ties with neighboring countries, resettlement policies, and shifting trade priorities. Gradually, the cow went from being the “worst type of livestock” (maldyn jamany siyr in Kazakh) to a prized possession siyr pul boldly in Kazakh).

In the Soviet era, this shift accelerated as emphasis was placed on industry, factory processing, and standardized raw material. Cow’s milk was more convenient for this system, while sheep were primarily raised for meat and wool. While Kazakhstan became famous for its production of wool and mutton by the 1960s, sheep’s milk, once the backbone of nomadic life, gradually faded into the background and out of people’s lives.

Personal reflections

Last summer, while working on an article about kurt, our team realized we had been oversimplifying our understanding of this product. Kurt is much more than just food; it embodies ideas about nourishment, the body, memory, and land.

I was most intrigued by the idea that sheep kurt was far more nutritious than cow kurt, and wanted to taste it for myself. Why, after living my whole life in Kazakhstan, had I never tried sheep kurt? Today, you can easily find kurt made with cow, camel and goat milk, but never sheep. Why do we hardly ever hear about sheep’s milk, when only a century ago it was the foundation of nomadic culture?

According to experts, in Kazakhstan, sheep’s milk is not produced on an industrial scale. Sheep are instead bred for their meat.

I set out to look for communities where sheep milking is still practiced. That search brought us to the home of two grandparents, Nesipkhan and Rozikul, who allowed us to see the process and taste the milk for ourselves.

At first, we wanted to see the milking up in the mountains on the summer pasture, but the pasture is only accessible on horseback, and the climb takes as long as two hours. Instead, they suggested visiting the village, as the flock is brought down there at the end of the summer.

“That white one on the edge. Take her, her udder’s filling up,” says Rozikul.

Elzhas, the grandson, skillfully catches the sheep by the hind leg and holds it close to him. The animal struggles for a moment, then quickly calms down. It’s held firmly, but never harshly. Rozikul sits down beside it, bucket in hand, and with a faint, almost inaudible sound, milk trickles down into the metal bucket. This brief moment offers a glimpse of the pillars which encapsulate pastoral life, knowledge being passed from elder to younger, while humans and animals share the same space. It is difficult to translate these moments into words.

Lessons in mastery

Nesipkhan, a well-respected shepherd in the region, has been raising sheep since 1981. His family still follows the traditional seasonal pattern where sheep are taken up to the mountains to graze on the pasture in the summer, and back down to the desert in the winter.

“For thirty years, I had to fight wolves to protect the flock. But three years ago, they all disappeared,” Nesipkhan told us. This, he feels, is very metaphorical. It reflected his strong connection to his herd, a statement of authority and mastery earned over time.

Changing seasons

The milking season starts in early August, when the young lambs are separated from their mothers. Once they are separated, the milk does not stop immediately, so this is when farmers are able to milk the sheep. At first, this is every other day, then every two days, and gradually less often until, after three to four weeks, the milk dries up on its own. Doing it any other way would be “malga obal,” harmful to the animal, as people here say.

According to Rozikul, milking 250–300 sheep during this period can yield around 70kg of kurt and a couple of karyn mai, butter stored in a sheep’s stomach, each weighing roughly 5–6kg.

By the end of the lactation period, the amount of milk drops significantly. Sheep naturally produce the most milk during the first 60 days, then the yield steadily declines.

If Rozikul were to milk the sheep throughout the entire season, production levels would be far higher. However, that is not the aim of this practice. Milking is not “tradition for tradition’s sake,” but a sacred knowledge passed down through hands, gestures, and the everyday rhythm of pasture life. It is less about economic gain and more about participating in the natural cycle of caring for animals and sustaining the bond between humans and the herd.

Rozikul and Nesipkhan’s practice of herding and milking sheep seems like an exception today. A century ago, sheep’s milk was the basis of the dairy culture in Kazakhstan, but gradually this practice faded into the background.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the preservation of a traditional, culturally significant practice of sheep milking and making kurt in Kazakhstan, which has largely disappeared. This preservation of heritage has positive cultural and nutritional implications, connecting people to their history and sustainable pastoral practices. The story provides detailed context about the tradition, its decline, and current efforts to maintain it, which can inspire curiosity and respect for cultural heritage.
articles.personality_title: Kazakh villagers keep the tradition of sheep’s milk and kurt alive
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For hundreds of years, sheep’s milk was the main source of dairy in Kazakhstan. Until the early 1900s, most dairy products came from sheep, not cows. Over time, cows became more common due to changes in farming and trade, and sheep’s milk use decreased.

**What happened** – A historian and reporter visited a remote valley in southern Kazakhstan where a few families still milk sheep and make kurt, a dried cheese snack from fermented sheep’s milk. This tradition, rare today, is kept alive by elders Nesipkhan and Rozikul, who showed how they milk their sheep and make dairy products by hand.

**Impact** – This tradition connects people to their history and nature. Sheep’s milk is more nutritious than cow’s milk, and making kurt is more than food—it is part of the culture and way of life. The practice shows how humans and animals live closely together, and how knowledge passes from older to younger generations.

**What’s next step** – Although sheep milking is rare now and mostly for meat production, the story highlights efforts to preserve this knowledge. Sharing these traditions might encourage more people to appreciate and protect them, helping keep a unique part of Kazakh culture alive.

**One-sentence takeaway** – In a remote Kazakh valley, families maintain the rare and nutritious tradition of milking sheep and making kurt, preserving a vital link to their nomadic heritage.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des villageois kazakhs préservent la tradition du lait de brebis et du kurt
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Pendant des centaines d’années, le lait de brebis était la principale source de produits laitiers au Kazakhstan. Jusqu’au début des années 1900, la plupart des produits laitiers venaient des brebis, pas des vaches. Avec le temps, les vaches sont devenues plus courantes à cause des changements dans l’agriculture et le commerce, et l’utilisation du lait de brebis a diminué.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Une historienne et journaliste a visité une vallée isolée dans le sud du Kazakhstan où quelques familles trient encore les brebis pour leur lait et fabriquent du kurt, une collation traditionnelle de fromage séché à base de lait fermenté de brebis. Cette tradition, rare aujourd’hui, est préservée par les aînés Nesipkhan et Rozikul qui ont montré comment ils traitent les brebis et fabriquent les produits laitiers à la main.

**Impact** – Cette tradition relie les gens à leur histoire et à la nature. Le lait de brebis est plus nutritif que le lait de vache, et la fabrication du kurt est plus qu’un aliment : c’est une part de la culture et du mode de vie. Cette pratique montre comment les humains et les animaux vivent en harmonie, et comment le savoir se transmet des plus âgés aux plus jeunes.

**Prochaine étape** – Même si la traite des brebis est rare aujourd’hui et que les brebis sont surtout élevées pour leur viande, cette histoire met en lumière les efforts pour préserver ce savoir-faire. Partager ces traditions pourrait encourager plus de personnes à les apprécier et à les protéger, aidant ainsi à garder vivante une partie unique de la culture kazakhe.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Dans une vallée isolée du Kazakhstan, des familles maintiennent la rare et nutritive tradition de la traite des brebis et de la fabrication du kurt, préservant un lien essentiel avec leur héritage nomade.
articles.personality_title_es: Pobladores kazajos mantienen viva la tradición de la leche de oveja y el kurt
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante cientos de años, la leche de oveja fue la principal fuente de productos lácteos en Kazajistán. Hasta principios del siglo XX, la mayoría de los productos lácteos provenían de las ovejas, no de las vacas. Con el tiempo, las vacas se hicieron más comunes debido a cambios en la agricultura y el comercio, y el uso de la leche de oveja disminuyó.

**Qué pasó** – Una historiadora y periodista visitó un valle remoto en el sur de Kazajistán donde algunas familias todavía ordeñan ovejas y hacen kurt, un bocadillo tradicional de queso seco hecho con leche fermentada de oveja. Esta tradición, rara hoy en día, la mantienen vivos los ancianos Nesipkhan y Rozikul, quienes mostraron cómo ordeñan a sus ovejas y elaboran los productos lácteos a mano.

**Impacto** – Esta tradición conecta a las personas con su historia y la naturaleza. La leche de oveja es más nutritiva que la de vaca, y hacer kurt es más que comida: es parte de la cultura y la forma de vida. La práctica muestra cómo humanos y animales viven juntos y cómo el conocimiento se transmite de mayores a jóvenes.

**Próximo paso** – Aunque el ordeño de ovejas es raro hoy y las ovejas se crían principalmente para carne, esta historia destaca los esfuerzos para preservar este conocimiento. Compartir estas tradiciones podría ayudar a que más personas las valoren y protejan, manteniendo viva una parte única de la cultura kazaja.

**Resumen en una frase** – En un valle remoto de Kazajistán, familias mantienen la rara y nutritiva tradición de ordeñar ovejas y hacer kurt, preservando un vínculo vital con su herencia nómada.
